title-group.article-title: "Ars Erotica" or "Scientia Sexualis"?: Narrative Vicissitudes in D. H. Lawrence's "Women in Love"

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 1996 The Journal of Narrative Technique

ref.mixed-citation: Reader 347-48

Foucault rarely makes explicit reference to Eastern systems of thought in his writings, nevertheless, as Uta Schaub observes, "[h]is surface text allows us to trace elements of Oriental philosophy, religion, and kindred forms of Western mysticism and to assume that they constitute a generative code beneath much of his discourse" (307)
Eliade 204, 250
Reader 347

Mircea Eliade gives an excellent account of these treatises, analyzing the iconographies (the mental images of the divinities), the physical postures, the body-touchings, the ritual sexual intercourse employed for attaining the "supreme truth" (200-73).
Psychoanalysis and the Question of the Text, ed. Geoffrey Hartman
Discourse in Psychoanalysis and Literature, ed. Shlomith Rimmon-Kenan
Meredith Skura (The Literary Use of the Psychoanalytic Process)
Daniel Gunn (Psychoanalysis and Fiction)
Donald Spence (Narrative Truth and Historical Truth: Meaning and Interpretation in Psychoanalysis)
Reading for the Plot (90-112)
History 59
Krafft-Ebing's functional theory of the sexual instinct, for example, generates a sharp division between normal and pathological states (34-36)
Three Essays (45-87)
Krafft-Ebing's fourfold classification of the perversions (34-36)
Psychoanalysis 204
"Unconscious" 167-210
History 158
Elizabeth Wright (49-55)
Anne Fernihough (61-82)
Gerald Doherty's essay, which traces in detail the correspondences between the representation of Ars Erotica practices in Women in Love and Tantric erotic rituals of initiation (211-22)
Three Essays 79
Three Essays 110-11
Eliade 245-49
Three Essays 75
